byline.contributor: Eric Lichtblau reported from Washington, and Monica Davey from Chicago. Ashley Southall contributed reporting from New York, and Gardiner Harris from Washington.
byline.original: By ERIC LICHTBLAU and MONICA DAVEY

abstract: Major Cities Chiefs Police Assn releases data showing spike in homicide rates in over 20 American cities, with concurrent significant drop in murder rate in almost as many cities; experts differ on what is causing shifts, but members of MCCPA, along with other law enforcement experts, dispute FBI director James Comey's assertion that rising crime is due to proliferation of Internet videos that have made officers reluctant to aggressively confront suspects.
lead_paragraph: The rise in homicides in cities like Chicago and Dallas has been linked by the F.B.I. director to less aggressive policing stemming from a “viral video effect.”

headline.main: Homicide Rates Jump in Many Major U.S. Cities, New Data Shows
headline.print_headline: New Data on Homicide Rates Rekindles a Debate

snippet: The rise in homicides in cities like Chicago and Dallas has been linked by the F.B.I. director to less aggressive policing stemming from a “viral video effect.”
